PLB105.name: Plant Biology
PLB105.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PLB105.description: Plant structure, function, development, genetics, diversity and ecology.

PLB106.name: Plant Biology Laboratory
PLB106.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PLB106.description: Cell structure, anatomy, physiology, growth and development, and diversity of plants.

PLB162.name: Organismal and Population Biology
PLB162.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLB162.description: Biological diversity and organismal biology. Principles of evolution, transmission genetics, population biology, community structure, ecology.

PLB172.name: Organismal and Population Biology Laboratory
PLB172.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLB172.description: Nature and process of organismal biology including experimental design, statistical methods, hypothesis testing in genetics, ecology, and evolution.

PLB182H.name: Honors Organismal and Population Biology
PLB182H.description: Diversity and basic properties of organisms, with emphasis on genetic principles, ecological interactions, and the evolutionary process. Historical approach to knowledge discovery.

PLB192H.name: Honors Organismal and Population Biology Laboratory
PLB192H.description: Nature and process of organismal biology, including experimental design and statistical methods, hypothesis testing, genetics, ecology, and evolution.

PLB203.name: Biology of Plants
PLB203.description: Evolution and diversification of plants. Structural innovations and physiological attributes of vascular land plants. Career opportunities, developing professional practices and Responsible Conduct of Research (RCR).
PLB203.prerequisite: (BS 162 or concurrently) or (LB 144 or concurrently) or (BS 182H or concurrently)

PLB218.name: Plants of Michigan
PLB218.description: Plant taxa of Michigan and the Great Lakes region and the major habitats in which they occur. Principles and rationale of classification. Relationships between life histories, morphology and environment.
PLB218.prerequisite: BS 162 or PLB 105 or LB 144 or BS 182H

PLB301.name: Introductory Plant Physiology
PLB301.description: General principles of plant physiology relating plant structure to function. Cell physiology, water relations, effects of light and temperature, respiration, photosynthesis, mineral nutrition, and hormone action.
PLB301.prerequisite: {CEM 141 or CEM 151 or LB 171 or CEM 181H} and ((PLB 105 or BS 161 or LB 145 or BS 181H) and completion of Tier I writing requirement)

PLB319.name: Introduction to Earth System Science
PLB319.description: Systems approach to Earth as an integration of geochemical, geophysical, biological and social components. Global dynamics at a variety of spatio-temporal scales. Sustainability of the Earth system.

PLB341.name: Fundamental Genetics
PLB341.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLB341.description: Principles of heredity in animals, plants and microorganisms. Classical and molecular methods in the study of gene structure, transmission, expression and evolution.
PLB341.prerequisite: (BS 161 or LB 145 or BS 181H) and (BS 162 or LB 144 or BS 182H)

PLB355.name: Ecology
PLB355.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLB355.description: Interrelationships of plants and animals with each other and the environment. Principles of individual, population, community, and ecosystem ecology. Application of ecological principles to global change and other anthropogenic stressors.

PLB355L.name: Ecology Laboratory (W)
PLB355L.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLB355L.description: Population, community, and ecosystem ecology, utilizing plant and animal examples to demonstrate general field principles.
PLB355L.prerequisite: (IBIO 355 or concurrently) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

PLB358.name: Streams to Gulf: Environmental Change in America's Deep South
PLB358.description: A study away course of anthropogenic impacts, habitat alteration, and environmental policy in surrounding water.

PLB400.name: Introduction to Bioinformatics
PLB400.description: Managing and analyzing biological data with bioinformatic tools, basic programming, and statistics.
PLB400.prerequisite: (STT 200 or STT 201 or STT 231 or STT 421) and (PLB 203 or MMG 201 or BMB 200 or BS 161)

PLB402.name: Biology of Fungi
PLB402.description: Characteristics, habitats, and diversity of major groups of fungi. Ecologic and economic importance of fungi.
PLB402.prerequisite: BS 162 or BS 161 or PLB 105 or LB 144 or LB 145 or BS 182H or BS 181H

PLB407.name: Diseases and Insects of Forest and Shade Trees
PLB407.description: Diseases, insects, and environmental problems affecting trees in forests, parks, suburbs, and nurseries. Methods of control.
PLB407.prerequisite: (PLB 105 or BS 162 or LB 144) and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

PLB410.name: Bioinformatics and Computational Biology
PLB410.description: Computational approaches in modern biology with a focus on applications in genomics, systems biology, evolution, and structural biology.
PLB410.prerequisite: {(CMSE 201 and LB 144 and LB 145) or (CMSE 201 and BS 161 and BS 162) or (CMSE 201 and BS 181H and BS 182H)} and (STT 200 or STT 201 or STT 231 or STT 421 or STT 351 or ECE 280)

PLB415.name: Plant Physiology
PLB415.description: Principles of plant metabolism, growth, and development. Photosynthesis, water relations, nitrogen metabolism, and cell wall biosynthesis. Environmental and hormonal factors that control plant growth and development. Gene regulation and genetic engineering of plants.
PLB415.prerequisite: (CEM 143 or CEM 251 or CEM 351) and (BS 161 or LB 145 or BS 181H)

PLB416L.name: Plant Physiology Laboratory
PLB416L.description: Experimental methods and experiment design in plant physiology and molecular biology, with emphasis in photosynthesis, water relations, plant growth, plant development, genetics and gene regulation. Communication of scientific information in written and graphical format.
PLB416L.prerequisite: (CEM 143 or CEM 351 or CEM 251) and (BS 161 or LB 145 or BS 181H) and (PLB 415 or concurrently) and (BS 171 or BS 191H or approval of department)

PLB418.name: Plant Systematics
PLB418.semester: Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLB418.description: Classification and evolution of higher plants, with emphasis on identification, characteristics of plant families, and systematic theory and practice.
PLB418.prerequisite: PLB 105 or BS 162 or LB 144 or BS 182H

PLB424.name: Algal Biology
PLB424.semester: Fall of even years, Summer of odd years
PLB424.description: Algal taxonomy, systematics, physiology, ecology, and environmental assessment. Lab focus on identification of freshwater algal genera collected from regional habitats.
PLB424.prerequisite: (BS 162 or LB 144 or BS 182H) and ((BS 172 or BS 192H) and completion of Tier I writing requirement)

PLB434.name: Plant Structure and Function
PLB434.description: Plant morphology and anatomy from a structural and functional perspective. Ecological and evolutionary significance of variation in the physiology and development of plant cells, tissues, meristems and organs.
PLB434.prerequisite: (BS 161 and BS 162) or (LB 144 and LB 145) or (BS 181H and BS 182H)

PLB440.name: Field Ecology and Evolution
PLB440.description: Solving conceptual and practical research problems in ecology and evolution under field conditions.

PLB441.name: Plant Ecology
PLB441.description: Ecology of plants and their communities. Effects of biotic and climatological factors influencing global distribution of plant communities. Community structure and function, microclimatology, ecophysiology, and adaptation.
PLB441.prerequisite: (BS 162 or LB 144 or IBIO 355 or BS 182H) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

PLB443.name: Restoration Ecology
PLB443.description: Principles of ecological restoration of disturbed or damaged ecosystems. Design, implementation, and presentation of restoration plans. Field trips required.

PLB445.name: Evolution (W)
PLB445.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLB445.description: Processes of evolutionary change in animals, plants. Microbes. Population genetics, microevolution, speciation, adaptive radiation, macroevolution. Origin of Homo sapiens.
PLB445.prerequisite: (IBIO 341 or CSS 350) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

PLB480.name: Epigenetics
PLB480.description: Molecular mechanisms of epigenetic modifications of eukaryotic genomes and their roles in biological processes, human diseases and cancer, plant development, and production.

PLB485.name: Tropical Biology
PLB485.description: Tropical biota emphasizing evolutionary and ecological principles compared across tropical ecosystems.
PLB485.prerequisite: (IBIO 355) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

PLB490.name: Directed Studies
PLB490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLB490.description: Directed study of published literature in an area of plant biology.
PLB490.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

PLB490H.name: Honors Directed Studies
PLB490H.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLB490H.description: Directed study of published literature in an area of plant biology.
PLB490H.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

PLB495.name: Botanical Garden Internship
PLB495.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLB495.description: Activities, functions and organization of botanical gardens. Principles of live plant curation.

PLB498.name: Undergraduate Research
PLB498.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLB498.description: Laboratory and/or field research in an area of plant biology.
PLB498.prerequisite: (BS 161 and BS 162 and BS 171 and BS 172) or (LB 144 and LB 145) or ((BS 181H and BS 182H and BS 191H and BS 192H) and completion of Tier I writing requirement)

PLB499.name: Senior Seminar (W)
PLB499.description: A capstone experience that focuses on current developments and issues in plant biology. Scientific writing and oral presentation.
PLB499.prerequisite: (PLB 498) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

PLB801.name: Foundations of Plant Biology
PLB801.description: An introduction to the history and current status of major research questions in plant biology, and approaches used to answer them.

PLB802.name: Selected Topics in Plant Biology
PLB802.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLB802.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in College of Natural Science or College of Agriculture and Natural Resources.

PLB804.name: Frontiers in Plant Biology
PLB804.description: Introduction to new and emerging research directions in the plant sciences, and provide tools needed for professional development.

PLB805.name: Special Problems in Physiology and Biochemistry
PLB805.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLB805.description: Faculty directed individualized study of a selected problem.
PLB805.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in College of Natural Science or College of Agriculture and Natural Resources.

PLB806.name: Special Problems in Genetics and Molecular Biology
PLB806.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLB806.description: Faculty directed individualized study of a selected problem.
PLB806.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in College of Natural Science or College of Agriculture and Natural Resources.

PLB807.name: Special Problems in Mycology
PLB807.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLB807.description: Faculty directed individualized study of a selected problem.
PLB807.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in College of Natural Science or College of Agriculture and Natural Resources.

PLB809.name: Special Problems in Ecology, Systematics, and Evolution
PLB809.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLB809.description: Faculty directed individualized study of a selected problem.
PLB809.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in College of Natural Science or College of Agriculture and Natural Resources.

PLB810.name: Theories and Practices in Bioinformatics
PLB810.description: Theories and algorithms behind bioinformatics tools. Basic tool development by writing scripts in the Python programming language for data analysis.

PLB812.name: Principles and Applications of Plant Genomics
PLB812.description: Foundations, principles, and applications of genome sequencing, genome analysis, expression profiling, and systems biology with respect to plant biology.

PLB815.name: Molecular Plant Sciences Seminar
PLB815.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PLB815.description: Critical analysis of current literature based on student presentations.

PLB820.name: Plant Reproductive Biology and Polyploidy
PLB820.description: Genetic processes underlying variations in plant reproductive biology and polyploidy. Utilization of these characteristics in plant breeding.

PLB826.name: Tropical Biology: An Ecological Approach
PLB826.description: Principles of tropical ecology at the population, community, and ecosystem levels. Given at various sites in Costa Rica by the Organization for Tropical Studies.

PLB828.name: Molecular Ecology and Conservation Genetics
PLB828.description: Population and evolutionary genetic principles applied to ecology, conservation, and management of fish and wildlife at the individual, population, and species level.

PLB830.name: Statistical Methods in Ecology and Evolution I
PLB830.description: Fundamental elements of data analysis in ecology and evolution. Programming fundamentals in the R computing language. Introduction to modeling biological data with modern methods for estimation and inference.
PLB830.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Entomology or in the Ecology, Evolutionary Biology and Behavior Specialization or in the Ecology, Evolutionary Biology and Behavior Major or approval of department.

PLB831.name: Statistical Methods in Ecology and Evolution II
PLB831.description: Advanced interpretation and modeling of biological data with modern methods for estimation and inference using the R computing language.
PLB831.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Entomology or in the Ecology, Evolutionary Biology and Behavior Specialization or in the Ecology, Evolutionary Biology and Behavior Major or approval of department.

PLB847.name: Advanced Mycology
PLB847.description: Systematics, identification, physiology, genetics, and molecular biology of plant pathogenic fungi.

PLB849.name: Evolutionary Biology
PLB849.description: Major conceptual, theoretical and empirical questions in evolutionary biology. Readings and lectures are synthesized in student discussions and papers.

PLB855.name: Molecular Evolution: Principles and Techniques
PLB855.description: Current techniques used to characterize and compare genes and genomes. Genetic variation, assays of variation. Data analysis and computer use to conduct a phylogenetic analysis to compare organisms and infer relationships.

PLB856.name: Plant Molecular and Omic Biology
PLB856.description: Advanced genetics and molecular biology of higher plants.

PLB863.name: Environmental Plant Physiology
PLB863.description: Interaction of plant and environment. Photobiology, thermophysiology, and plant-water relations.

PLB864.name: Plant Specialized Metabolism
PLB864.description: Specialized metabolism unique to photosynthetic organisms including aspects of nitrogen and sulfate assimilation and essential amino acid synthesis relevant to specialized metabolism, vitamin synthesis, mono-, di-, tri- and tetra-terpenoid synthesis, synthesis of phenylpropanoids and other aromatic compounds and synthesis of various alkaloids.
PLB864.prerequisite: BMB 461 or BMB 462 or (PLB 866 or concurrently)

PLB865.name: Plant Growth and Development
PLB865.description: Genetics and molecular biology of development in higher plants as influenced by genes and environment. Biosynthesis, action and signal transduction of phytohormones and other signaling molecules. Initiation, formation and patterning of plant organs and cell types. Genetic mechanisms underlying developmental diversity.

PLB866.name: Molecular Plant Physiology
PLB866.description: Molecular basis of the physiology of plants including photosynthesis, respiration, primary metabolism, water relations, and nutrition. Quantitative and systems approaches are emphasized.

PLB884.name: Prokaryotic Diseases of Plants
PLB884.description: Prokaryotic genera associated with plant diseases. Genetics and host-pathogen interactions. Prokaryotic disease control strategies.

PLB891.name: Current Topics in Ecology and Evolution
PLB891.description: Presentation and critical evaluation of theoretical and empirical developments in ecology and evolutionary biology by visiting scientists.

PLB896.name: Population and Community Ecology
PLB896.description: Population dynamics of animals and plants utilizing life tables and projection matrices. Species interaction. Life history theory. Structure and dynamics of communities. Succession.

PLB897.name: Ecosystem Ecology and Global Change
PLB897.description: Structure and function of natural ecosystems and their responses to global environmental change. Biogeochemical cycles, food webs, energy flow, nutrient cycling, and ecosystem management and restoration.

PLB898.name: Population and Community Ecology Theory Laboratory
PLB898.description: Practical experience designing and analyzing mathematical models in ecology from single species to communities, food webs and ecosystems.

PLB899.name: Master's Thesis Research
PLB899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLB899.description: Research in anatomy, bryology cell biology, ecology, genetics, molecular biology, morphology, mycology, paleobotany, pathology, physiology and systematics.

PLB999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
PLB999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLB999.description: Research in anatomy, bryology, cell biology, ecology, genetics, molecular biology, morphology, mycology, paleobotany, pathology, physiology and systematics.
